text:
Aroma - caramel and toffee as well as some coriander spice.
Appearance - clean gold body with a white head.
Taste - some citrus framed by caramel and doughy malt. Some spice is present as well, and distinct yeast.
Palate - medium body, light carbonation

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Deep , hazy ,copper color ;medium-sized , yellowish head. Aroma of malt , fruits , some spices , hint of yeast. Taste follows . Not bad , but something is missed.

12oz bottle from Brewmasters in Wilson. Dark orange hue, normal clarity with almost fully diminishing off-white head. No lacing. Aroma was very dull, watery, light fruit (grape). Sweet light fruit taste up front with more of a light spice finish.

Type: 12-oz. bottle
Glass: Karl Strauss 26th anniversary snifter glass
From: Barons Market in Alpine, Calif. 
Price: $3.99
Purchased: July 18, 2015
Consumed: July 18, 2015
Misc.: N/A 

Poured a honey, caramel, hazy color with 1-to-2 fingers of off-white rocky head, which thinned out rather quickly. A few bubble streams coming up from the bottom along the sides. Poor lacing on the sides. Below average-to-poor retention. (Sight - 3.75)

Smelled honey, caramel, sour fruit, pear, apple and earthy notes, ending with sharp peppery cloves. (Smell - 4.13)

Taste pretty much follows the nose, although not as good. Got pear, apple peel, light apple juice, caramel, sour or slightly spoiled fruit, honey, pepper and candied cloves. (Taste - 3.75)

Light body. Creamy texture. Average carbonation. Abrupt finish. (Feel - 3.38)

This was only my third kind of this style, so Im not going to compare. This beer had its moments, but something just didnt work out as soon as it hit my lips. Great value for $3.99 a 6-pack though. (Overall - 3.75)

3.79 85 B+
Nice light spring beer. Not foamy and a light malty gold color. Good bridge beer between an Irish ale and a wit.
Light citrus. Some faint resin and a faintly tangy finish. Amber pour. Easy drinking but nothing special. Bottle from Glens.

Drank from a sampler glass at the Electric City Craft Brew Fest! Pours a hazy amber color, with little head. Slightly sweet aromas. A decent beer, I was hoping for more by South Hampton... The girl service was cute and knowledgable tho!

16oz pour at Nags Head in Huntington pours a hazy gold with some creamy, white head. Nose has a nice mix of yeast, mild gristy notes, some biscuit dough, a little potpurri, some flower petals, lightly grass. Flavor has some nice stone fruit notes to go along with things, crackery, yeast, biscuit, orange, grass, flower petals. Creamy finish. Solid offering.
Draft at Eulogy. Hazy orange pour with a foamy top. Some lace. Juicy amber fruit and honey wheat. Sour cherries. Peaches. Tangerines. Caramel toast. Creamier palate than expected. Interesting notes.

12 oz. bottle from Total Wine, Virginia Beach, VA. Deep reddish-orange pour with a frothy off-white head. Aroma of sweet caramel malt, cherry, and light citrus. Taste is not overly sweet but certainly malt forward with caramel and brown sugar upfront and tropical fruits that help to balance the overall flavor. This is an enjoyable and approachable enough session beer.
Tap @ Pour. Hazy amber iwth syrupy head and light lacing. Smells like a hefeweizen plus spice and fresh. Grassy. Dry light bitter finish + a little spice.
Deep orange, medium foamy offwhite head. Aroma is yeast, grass and spice. Flavor is toffee, caramel, cherry, fig, yeast and spice. Quite sweet.

Bottle at San Juan. 
Clear copper color, small off-white head. Caramel and grainy&grassy notes in the nose. Medium-bodied. Flavor is alcoholic, bready maltyness with herbal and grassy hops. Not maybe authentique but somewhere there. French ones are not better.
Bottle. Very slightly hazy bright amber color, white head. Aroma of earthy toffee. Taste is earthy with a bit of fruit. Nice.
Curious beer, much maltier than Ive come to expect in the style. Slightly mash-smelling, cereal, a bit of orange and maybe some brown pears. Interesting beer.

Pour otu of 12 oz bottle, hazy orange-yellow pour with white lacing head, aroma brought orange, vanilla, touch of butter, some peach notes into a bit of honey, some crackery notes. Taste is a mix of orange, pear, some bread, hints of biscuit into a bit of spice, touch of grass, finishing sweet. Pretty tasty.

12 oz bottle 
Pours clear amber with plenty of visible carbonation and a durable off-white head. 
Aroma: more like a pilsner than expected, with earthy hops showing. 
Flavor: certainly better than the aroma suggests. Moderate complexity. Mild bitterness in the finish and aftertaste. Bready malts with faint fruity and spicy notes. 
Feel: excellent creamy but lively feel with medium+ body.
Tap. Murky light brown. Good lasting head. Slighy sweet body. Decently full body. Strong notes of caramel and toffee, with a bit of drying yeast.

12oz bottle.  Amber pour some frothy head. Aroma of tangy fruity dead Belgian yeast big malts. Tastes like a doppelbock with some Belgian yeast. bready.  Sticky palate. Some skunky german-type hops coming through. probably was good in 750ml.  This mass produced 6pack is garbage.

Light amber, hazy, thin (1mm film) eggshell head with lively bubbles. Aroma is of hay, grass field, hint of old dry cheese (Parmesan?). Bit of soap. Body is medium, and syrupy, especially due to diffuse, prickly carbonation not pulling its weight. Flavor is dried/baked raw grain (wheat/oat), sharp grasses, again, bit of soap, touch of nectar sweetness. 12oz actually seems like a lot; not something Im tempted to toss down. OK.
Rocket City Brewfest, clear yellow with a white head. A: caramel, floral, herb. T: caramel, floral, fruit. Sweet finish with a medium light body.

Bottle. Pours an orangish color with white head. Malty, cereal oats, slight fruity aromas. Very fruit forward flavor that I wasnt expecting. Fruity, jolly rancher, oats flavors. I was really excited about this beer, because not a lot of breweries make biere de garde style. I wasnt expecting the strong fruity flavor, which seemed off.
Sampled at Rockecity Brewfest. Golden with thin off white head. Aroma of light yeast notes, caramel, some fruit, and spice. Light/medium body, yeast, caramel, and light spice

I dont have the opportunity to try Southampton beers that often, in my market, but I have been consistently impressed whenever I do. Straight away, this beer is beautiful to look at, presenting a brilliant gold/light copper color with great clarity and moderate head retention. The enticing nose offers aromas of spiced orange peel and sweet bread. Medium bodied, this delightfully drinkable ale offers well-balanced flavors of sweet, spicy malt and light hop bitterness, riding on a slightly sticky mouthfeel and prickly carbonation. At 6.5 % ABV, this is rather dangerously drinkable!
Bottle, aroma is light spice and mild caramel. Taste is similar, a pretty nice blend of lager and saison.

Aroma of orange peel and lemon grass and sweet spices. Hazy orange. Mainly a dry sweetness, tart fruit, and very bready - an element reflected in the body, which is crispy and heavy. This beer feels like any number of Americanized wheat ales released in summer, only with some farmhouse aspects mixed in for kicks.

Southampton Biere De Mars has a thick, spongy, white head, and a hazy, bubbly, amber appearance, and a pretty substantial lace curtain left behind. The aroma is evocative of wheat, for sure, but one will pick up subtle spices, sweetness, and a wonderful toasted malt. Taste is of sweet, spiced bread and a touch of hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium and soft, and Southampton Biere De Mars finishes semi-dry, a bit alcoholic, and quite drinkable. RJT
Yeasty barley aroma. Shimmering amber, thick head, good retention. Medium body, chewy, alcohol noticeable. Malty with only subtle apple highlights. Finishes with grass and apple core.

12 ounce bottle from Beer Crazy. This beers 351st rating. 
Pours pretty enough, a nice deep golden, bordering on a light orange... or rust... but solidly in the richer end of "golden" Its got a big head and nice lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is spicy & bready with some light fruitiness... like pear & pineapple but these are faint. Its mostly like a hearty bread with some cooking spice, decently pleasant. 

The fruitiness comes out much more strongly in the flavor, its got a good bit of pineapple flavor and the sort of sweet on tart character that goes along with that. The beer is spicy, enjoyably so & in a way that does a decent job balancing the fruit character. The bitterness is light but well integrated. Its got some yeasty & bready notes, but pulls those off without giving a terribly muddled character. 

The palate is sharp, prickly, and a touch heavy. 
Overall I think this is very enjoyable & it works pretty well as my last rating for the month of March.

12 ounce bottle from Beer Run. This beers 350th rating. Pours a slighly hazy copper with a large foamy tan head. Decent head retention. Aroma of canned pineapple, spice, toasted malt, faint marzipan. The taste is toasted malt, stone fruits, green apple, spice, yeast, mild nutty notes. Medium bodied, low carbonation. Not what I was expecting at all, but solid.

hazy gold to peach pour with a 1 finger, creamy off white head. Aroma is toast, cereal, light and tart Belgian fruity esters and a little citrus. Flavor is grainy pale malt, a little toast, doughy yeast, light spice, light tree and stone fruit and some earthy, planty hops tot the finish. Medium body with a light to medium, blanketing and somewhat sharp carbonation, oily entry and oily, but somewhat dry and lightly chalky finish. Good stuff overall, simple but satisfying.

Draught at Redbones, 3/14/14I was pretty excited to see this on tap, not having huge expectations, as its obviously the contract brewed (Susquehenna Brewing, I believe) version. But despite having mostly awful experiences with their drafts, you do occasionally get a good one (Keller Pils, Left Coast IPA).This was not to be the case.Clear amber body topped by a white head showing moderate retention.Sweet, simple, crystal malts in the nose followed by...more crystal malts and ending in...crystal malt. The slightest brush of Belgian yeast with a touch of fruitiness and light vanilla. Seemingly unhopped....In the mouth, we have the crystal malt from the nose and a similar lack of hops. Sure, biere de gardes arent hoppy styles, but I dont even taste bittering hops here. Its just all hard candy-like sweetness, buttercream, light raisins and a touch of red fruits. Absolutely unwaveringly simplistic, underattenuated and terribly cloying.Amazing that they were able to make a Belgian/French style this bad without any infections or technical flaws.Should have named it Southampton Single Malt Unhopped Series - Crystal 120.Maybe some day Ill get to try the real version (pictured).  Its really a shame these garbage contract versions get lumped in with the actual (good) bottled versions.

Bottle from Bruisin Ales. Pours orange with a thin white head. Doesnt have a lot of lacing. Has a slight fruitiness on the nose. Definitely get the fruitiness on the tongue. Theres like an apple thing on the finish. Its another solid beer from these guys.
12 ounce bottle thanks to Greg. Pale orange color. Slight fruit component but not dry or funky.

Bottle. Golden bodied with a short white head. Grainy and grassy nose with soft fruit notes and rife with yeast. Taste is toasted malt, light caramel, grains, bread, soft fruit, yeast and grass. Body is light-medium with a strong, effervescent carbonation. Ends with more toasted malt, caramel notes, grains, toasted dark bread, yeast, ripe fruits and light grassy notes.
A hazy golden orange beer with a small white head. The aroma is grain, grass, lemon, floral. The flavor is lightly bitter, spicy, and peppery, a little fruity.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, no bottle dating. Pours lightly hazy bright orange color with a 1 finger dense white head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of caramel, toast, pear, apple, grape, bread, clove, pepper, floral, herbal, light coriander, and yeast earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of malt, spice, and yeast ester notes; with good strength. Taste of caramel, toast, bread, pear, apple, clove, pepper, light coriander, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness. Lingering notes of caramel, toast, bread, light fruits, clove, pepper, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Good balance and complexity of malt, spice, and yeast ester flavors; with decent robustness and no cloying flavors after the finish. A bit too dry on the flavors. Medium carbonation and body; with a smooth and crisp mouthfeel that is good. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a very good biere de garde style. Good complexity and balance of malt, spice, and yeast ester flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. Needed a bit more malt in the flavors, but otherwise a nicely enjoyable offering.

Poured from 12oz bottle. Very interesting take on the farmhouse style. Bitter throughout and complex. 

--you've been Dubbed.
12 oz. bottle. Very average in everyway. Bland but some spicy taste and medium body. On big closeout---because it wasnt selling!

No bottling information.
Appearance: The body is a brilliant dark amber to copper with a tall slightly off-white head that is persistent, settling into a creamy full coating. This is an excellent looking beer.
Aroma: The aroma is sweet leaning with some malts with a presence of watermelon and strawberry with hints of peppery spice. The malts are a tad musky and a bit weak, but smells nice.
Taste: The intro is slightly fruity of strawberry but quickly gains watermelon overtones that are prominent with a mild malt base and a peppery watermelon finish. The finish lingers a bit spicy and lasts a bit.
Palate: Medium bodied with mild carbonation.
Overall: What a pleasant beer. This is a Spring seasonal, but I would like this in the Winter. The lingering spicy finish is perfect for the Winter.

Pours a soft and lightly hazy peach flesh gold with one or two fingers of creamy off white head. Nose shows a nice fruity malt sweetness with notes of caramel and spicy hops. A light and earthy malt character shows as well. Flavor is nice, upfront malt sweetness and earthy malt profile. Some light bready notes and a spicy character. Medium bodied with a nice crisp character.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy amber color with very little head on it. Nose is decently sour and smells like a good saison, but without the funk on it. Taste has a little sweetness to it, and just some hint at some fruitiness. Not a huge fan of this, but its fairly drinkable.
Grainy aroma, golden amber medium bodied beer, light bitterness and fruit sweetness. Came in a run of the mill 12 ounce bottle, but better than expected.
Bottle. Cloudy dark orange pour, zesty head. Aroma is spice and herb. Strawberry and nectarine note in the herb flavour. Herb and hop in finish
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Nice orange/yellow color, crystal clear with a small off white head. Nice floral notes on the nose, maybe some rose petals, some ripe fruit, a little cherry and a nice kind of caramely malt note. Nice red fruits on the taste like cherry and strawberry, nice flowery notes, and a good malt presence. Great easy drinking and flavorful beer for those warmer days.

Did I get a bad bottle? Pours copper with a medium sized off white head that quickly disappears. The aroma seems to have some funky belgian yeast but little to nothing else. The taste seems like a lagerish brew with some off fruit.. Ill have to retry this if I see it on tap.

Bottle. Pours light clear gold with little head. Nose is like fruity pebbles with a little funk. Taste is similar but with a dusty wheat like finish. Decent malt backbone. Palate is a little too thin to not have much carb. Not all that wonderful. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
bottle. Golden with small head. Not particularly spicy or yeasty, and kind of lacking personality. Not awful, but just needs more flavor.

12 ounce bottle. Pours an orange amber color with a moderate rocky beige head. Grainy malt aroma with citrus notes. Tangy toasted malt flavor has hints of baked bread, citrus hops and earthy yeast. Medium bodied and flavorful with an underlying fruitiness. Finishes with light citrus and spicy hops.

Golden color out of the bottle with a quickly disappearing white head and a light, sweet spicy nose.  Honey sweetness with coriander spice, Mandarin orange and some orange marmalade on homemade bread.  Highly carbonated.  Okay beer, but not my favorite style.

Bottle. Pours a rich honey amber with a small white head. Aroma is lots of bread, a slight earthiness, faint hops.  Flavor is rich and bready, moderately sweet. Low bitterness. Medium, slightly thick mouthfeel.

Decent aroma and basic appearance with a complex taste and lingering mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour is a hazy copper with a small white head.  Aroma is a earthy, toffee malt with some caramel.  Flavor is caramel malt, some mild dark fruit and a mild spice.  Finish has some dark breadyness. This was a decent and different beer.
Aroma is spicy yeast, citrus and hints of sugar and white bread.  The flavor is spices, candy/sugar, malts and a mildly hoppy/slightly dry finish.

12 oz. bottle, bonused to me by BrewtopiaofPJ (thanks Mark), pours a hazy rusted golden with a small off-white head. Aroma brings out traditional French biere de garde notes - some farmhouse notes, some tarnished metal, and some skunky notes. Flavour is more of the same, with old farmhouse notes, some earthy notes, and some vegetal notes. Very light-bodied and seems a bit "off". Never been a fan of this style, and this one certainly hasnt converted me.

12 oz bottle. Clear dark gold pour with thin white head. Light spicy aroma, grainy and peppery, very fresh, light fruitiness. Palate is very clean and very crisp, fresh grain, mild spicyness, ever so slight fruitiness, very lager like, bright. Palate is dry, alcohol is well hidden, medium carbonation. Excellent.

Beer from trade with jrgratz (though the bottle looks more pedestrian than the picture here).  Thanks! Pours clear copper with small white head.  Aroma smells like a lager/marzen.  Sweet malt with a hint of spice.  Flavor has up front yeast funk with a bit of spice and bitterness.  Lingering funk on the palate.  Light mouthfeel with medium-high carbonation.  Not bad.
On tap. Tastes like pilsner malt with some spices added. Tons of yeast, imparting more yeasty bitterness than funk. Boring overall; forgettable.

A bit of fruit and yeast, though particularly reserved in aroma.  Liquid gold in appearance - but very, very translucent.  Crisp, but the flavor is lacking - favoring more muscat than anything else.  Overly dry, on par with a very dry white wine.  The coupling of a sweet, fruit aroma and dry flavor is interesting, but the beer as a whole is far from exciting.

Pours a darker orange in color with a white head that fades rapidly.  Aroma has caramel, honey, spice, and orange.  The taste comes off as more malty initially, with the caramel standing out.  It then leads to more fruity flavors, being berries and orange.  However, the caramel flavors are retained throughout.  Medium in body with a thicker yet slick texture.  Aftertaste is honey, orange, and caramel.  Nothing really worth remembering.
Sour and salty taste, super cloudy. Salty aroma. Limey after taste. Thin palate.

Bottle. Pours a copper orange color with a small white head. Aroma of yeast, caramel, soft spices and some fruity esters. Flavor was earthy and yeasty with sweet malts, light fruit, subtle caramel and had a bit of honey.
Almost flat, spicy beer medium bitterness, hints of sweet candi and soy. Not the best.

On draft at the brass tap, poured a clear golden color with aromas of light fruit, yeast, sugar and some dill pickles.  Flavors are same less the pickles.  Light on the palate.  Ok overall, not something I would seek out again, interesting beer overall.

Bottle: Poured a hazy beige color ale with a rather large foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma consists of rustic malt with lightly sweet undertones. Taste is dominated by sweet notes upfront with some rustic malt and light fruity ester. This is probably a tad too sweet for my liking. Body is quite full with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. Good though probably tad more sweet then some of its overseas cousin.

12oz. bottle.
A - Pours a burnt orange. 1 finger head that gently lowers into a thin ceiling.

S - Aromas consist of citrusy yeast, sugary caramel, hints of cinnamon, sour/tart strawberries, hints of rose petals, spice.

T - Flavors start off peppery then a sweet creamy malt shows up. Slightly funky & bready yeast along side a constant sour citrus that balances nicely. At one point I almost got a slight sensation of saccharin on my tongue. Aftertaste is of funky muted hops. Very complex flavors going on.

A smooth and creamy beer with nice carbonation. The smells and flavors were all there and blended nicely. A pretty solid beer.

Serving type: bottle

07-28-2010

New Beer Distributors, NY 12oz ($2.25): Pours a clear orange with a really small, quickly dissipating white head. Aroma is fruits, sugar, a little bit of hops. Taste is slightly bitter. Somewhat sweet. Tastes like it might be a bit old, but it might be the natural taste. Aftertaste is lingering bitterness, with a  little bit of sugar on top. Easy to drink.
Bottle. Orange, fizzy white head that goes away. Nose is light fruits, spices. Taste is light fruits, sweet malts, some hint of  rooty vegetables.

Bottle into a goblet. Thanks Dave N. Aroma is a nice malt spice with a light hop. Pour is a nice dark hazy honey, with a very light head. Taste is a spice, sweetness with a malt back. Finish is a warm spice. A very good ale.
A nice lingering sweetness in the mouth.  Thin white head.  Burnt orange in color.  Caramel malts in nose, like a darker lager.  My first time with this style and I enjoyed it.
Draft at Wesley Chapel Brass Tap.  Pours a medium amber color with a foamed off white head.  Decent flavor and aroma with some malt sweetness and a bit of alcohol.

On tap at Blue Monk in Buffalo NY.  Served in a pint glass, somewhat golden colored and hazy.  I wasnt really very impressed by this.  Kinda fruity, which was ok, but way too sweet.  Almost syrupy.  Its a style I enjoy, but this one didnt do it for me.
12oz bottle. Pours an orange copper with a quickly receding head. Sweet malt and fruit flavors with a sticky palate.
Aroma of malted grain; hazy amber w/ no head; flava of malt w/ sweet + spice notes; feels full and chewy w/ some zing; finishes long time, sweet and tobaccoey. Nice brew!

12 ounce bottle thanks to Dallas. Pours a dark copper color with a tiny white head. The aroma is sweet caramel and light yeast. An interesting flavor of bitterness and candies, earthy dry, some yeast, caramel. Nice.

12oz bottle shared by Dallas 
Appearance: Clear golden with a small white head and light lacing. Aroma and taste was sweet caramel, honey and herbal. It was OK, sweet.
Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. The aroma is fruity, earthy, malty, hint of alcohol. The flavor is strong malt character, caramel, earthy, floral. Very tasty.

Highly carbonated amber ginger ale appearance with a light head. Cigar wood nose accompanies by a soft breeze of melanoidin maltyness. Cidery wood body, gently malt ball touches with a mix of earthy and fruity hops through the finish.
Poured a clear golden with a smallish head. Bready malts and semi-sweet. Interesting, but not my style.

Dark gold; copper-orange. Finger of puffy head. Cloudy but looks very refreshing.

Aroma is very spicy, with hints of lemon and orange zest. A hint of clove. The aroma isnt that strong, but it is pleasant.

The malt in the flavor is very Euro-German heavy; slightly sweet but a little sharp. As it warms up, the sweeter flavors come out; slight caramel and hint of butterscotch. Less spicy than in the nose, and more sweet.

Feels very buttery and soft. It is a sweet ale with just a touch of spice.

Draft @ Coalhouse Pizza in Stamford, CT. Poured a clear, auburn color, this beer is a fruity, tart ale that has lots of characteristics of Kriek style beer. With an almost champagne-like mouth feel this beer is tasty, but lacks the complexity of notes like Ommegangs offering in this style. Still, very tasty, good summer beer.

Pours deep gold with compact short lived head.  Biscuit dipped honey aromas... Crisp sweet finish creamy mouthfeel. Good French style beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Hazy deep orange-amber color with a medium off-white head. Aroma of fruit esters, malt, some caramel and honey, yeast, some spiciness and an alcohol note. Sweet malty fruity flavor with some honey, a bit of caramel and a slightly drier and slightly spicy finish with a bit of alcohol. Medium-bodied. Too sweet and simple, kinda disappointing.
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 Tap at Iron Abbey. Orange amber pour with minimal head. Fruity, with some herbal and earthy elements. Very nice.

On sample at southampton publick house.
Now were getting somewhere. This sample has a nice malty presence as well as fresh hops which makes it pleasant.

12 oz bottle.  Clear yellow, fizzy.  Too much vanilla, esters, otherwise bland, thick on the tongue, sticky sweet, when it should be light and spritzy.  I remember it being better out of the bigger bottles.
Bottle.  Slightly sour, stale barley malt aroma.   Dark golden yellow color with minimal head.  Mildly sweet barley malt and lightly bitter herbal hops flavor.  Pretty good - nice beer.

Draught @ Cambridge House:  This one pours a crystal clear, slightly darker amber color.  There was just a wisp of an off white head that still left some lacing.  There is a pleasant nose to it.  Mainly malts and some fruits.  Hints of Belgian yeast also.  The taste is also very good.  Just a touch Belgian style sweet.  Caramel malts, some fruits and earthy hops.  Very smooth and easy drinking.  A nice beer.

Pours a crisp ruby/pear with a brief whisp of a head... no real lacing and a bit of beading forced by the etching.

The nose is pretty nice. Orange, wheat, light spice, some sweeter malts, not much for hops.

The taste is pretty dull - muted fruits and hops, this was extrad to me and I have to believe that this ones too old... no freshness date but all the indicators are there.

Id gladly give this one a shot again if I knew how fresh it was. Until then Ill have to pass.
bright and crisp in the beginning, almost like a cider finishes mildly hoppy. no real maltiness to speak of, just yeast and hops mostly. its ok.

On draft at Cajun Cafe Spring Beer Fest 2012.  Pours a caramel orange color with a white head.  Nose is caramel, light fruit, and some mild spices.  Flavor is similar- caramel in the front, some mild fruit and spices in the back.  Enjoyable bier de garde.

Medium amber lightly cloudy with a frothy head. Aromas of pineapple, light citrus hops, coriander spice in the back. Flavors of citrus hops, sweet caramel balance, with a hint of spice coming through, and light apricot. Sweet with a decent balence of hops and malt.
Copper color in the glass. Aroma of toasted, bready malt. Fairly malty profile overall. Hint of caramel.

Aroma is clove, banana, citrus and cinnamon. Taste is complex, a bit off putting at first but it grew on me. Taste is strong floral hops, caramel malts, cloves and other peppery spices. Some cereal sweetness, I find unappealing. Some sugar candy sweetness  and some bright fresh fruits, banana mostly maybe some citrus. Pretty decent, seems more like an autumn beer.

Bottle.  Pours gold and orange with a small white head.  Aromas of sweet honey, raspberry, grass, wheat, and plum.  The flavor is honey and lavender, sweet, with sugary dried fruit.  Sweet and malty with a light grassy bitterness.  Medium carbonation and body.  Nice.  [1023]

Pours copper-orange with a white skim of head.
Scent is light, fruity,malt, spices, bread.
Taste is a bit of grass, sweet toffee, pear,
Very enjoyable.  Light, soft, sweet.

A medium copper colored brew. Little head. Decent carbonation though. Light sweet malty aromas. Flavor is of sweet toffee. Fruit is minimal. Some yeast-spice notes. Smooth and very drinkable. Kinda like good Alt style brew.
Pours a copper color. Smell is mild, a tad sweet. Taste is sweet, malty, a touch of spice and just a bit of bitterness at the finish. Overall an enjoyable beer.
Nice light tan color with an off white head. Smooth malty goodness with a wonderful floral nose and flavor that made it a wonderful addition to the blue cheese steak salad I paired it with. Yum.
Light golden with little white head on pour. Grassy notes and some spice in the aroma. Smooth finish like a cream ale.
Bottle, interesting stuff. A little bitter. A fair bit of life. But there really seems to be no consistence to this style. But this is interesting.

A hazed golden beer with a thick frothy and lacing off white head. In aroma, a very herbaceous malt with German-like hops. In mouth, a smooth grassy malt with light mineral notes, some light spices, like coriander, cloves, a bit of chalkyness in finale.
Pours amber with a white head and light carbonation.  Aroma is grass, pear and bread.  Taste is spicy sweet.  Very soft and smooth mouth feel with the low carbonation.

Pours a dark golden copper with a minimal tan head. Smells fresh and fruity, apple comes through. Taste of sweet fruits, caramel malts, nuts, and some hop bitterness at the end. Med carbonation. This is not bad, but not outstanding. It is refreshing and easy to drink.

Tap @ Grand Cru in Rhinebeck...  Poured golden/amber with a thin head that faded quickly.  Caramel malts, butterscotch, low bitterness and fruity esters.  Nose wasnt all that great, a little buttery.  Leafy earthiness.  Some yeast spiciness, squash and honey grain sweetness.

A: Orange/yellow with a eggshell white thin head... good lacing throughout...

S: Lemons highlight a sweet grainy background... a blend of soft spices

T: Sweet malts and lemon citrus accents form the front of the flavor profile while the tart grainyness comes through towards the end... some peach/orange accents in there as well...

M: Medium bodied with a lot of character... 

O: Good... not quite a saison... interesting feel and the balance of the spices make this a nice treat

Grabbed bottle as part of mix six at Nikkis in RI where i was surprised on variety of Ny brew.  Pours an ugly dirty orange with small head.  Nose of yeast and tropical fruit.  tastes of vanilla, tangerine, banana, yeast, floral, hay, and toffee.  Not really my thing but interesting none the less

Bottle.  Pours a translucent medium amber with a decent white head.  Aroma is heavy on the caramel malts and some earthy funk along with some frutiy esters.  Taste is initially ripened fruit (heavy raisin and plum) with a sweetness and caramel malt.  The yeast is not overpowering, but know.  This almost had a slight wine qualiity to it.  Not really my cup of tea, but an intersting brew nonetheless.

A nice copper / bronze hue on the pour with a small short lived white head. Aroma of sweet malt, some light floral citrus hops and nice spicy fruity notes. Taste is sweet malt some nice spicy fruitiness some light hops and maybe some light vanilla flavoring. Palate is nice smooth slightly creamy texture, medium body with moderate carbonation. Finish is sweet caramel malt some light hops ending in slightly spicy fruitiness with some light vanilla flavoring. Overall a very nicely balance and flavorful brew.

Appearance:  clear brassy amber, short fizzy off-white head, bit of lace.   Aroma: sweet fruits, fresh-cut flowers, some yeast, bit of malt.   Taste: crackery, lightly toasted malts over a bit of restrained yeasty spice.   Finish: clean, short, almost flavorless.   Notes: Almost like an amber ale, minus most of the hops.  Certainly more restrained than their regular Biere de Garde, and extremely drinkable.  Just not a ton going on here.

Bottle.  Dark copper pour with just a thin head.  The aroma is overtly yeasty, with a bit of tropical fruit.  Somewhat surprisingly, the beer drinks with a brusque malty flavor up front, caramel even, an almost complete 180 from the initial whiff.  Still flavorful and fun, not at all what youd expect.  (#4267, 9/25/2011)

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured a hazy yellow color with an average white frothy head that lasted and produced good lacing. Moderate yeasty and sweet citrus aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium yeast sweet flavor with a smooth citrus sweet finish of average duration. Soft drinkable brew.

Malty and slightly floral with orange tones. Not very much carbonation and no finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750 ml bottle 08 vintage (71/250).  Pours a clear golden color with a small white head.  The aroma is mildly sweet, herbal and floral, light fruits and a touch of yeast.  The flavor has light to medium sweet malt, moderate fruitiness, lighter herbal notes with a touch of yeast.  This bottle was found deep in the cellar, so unfortunately this was a touch past its prime.

In bottle at the Knickerbocker. Light sweet malt aroma, biscuit and a bit of spicy rye notes. Mild butterscotch, weak hops. Hazy medium amber body with thin white head. Medium body with high carbonation. Starts medium sweet with caramel, biscuit, and mild spice. Dry carbonic acidity, light hop dryness, a bit of butterscotch. Finish is fairy dry with light bitterness. Taste is fairly true to style and reminiscent of the biere de gardes I had in Northern France.

12oz bottle, not the cork wiring top.  This is my first Biere De Garde, actually, I usually would not have bought this if it wasnt for rating it.  I have to admit, this is not my style.  The beer poured golden brown color, very little head, lively CO2.  Aroma of fruits, bread dough and malts.  So far not bad.  Again, the flavor is not for me.  I dont get a lot of balance or complexity, just a brew that taste sweet and uneventful.  Although, the ratings show that this is a popular beer, just not for me.  I have nothing to compare the taste to, so I trust the other raters this is on style.

This beer is very hard to categorize. Pours a golden/brown with a head that quickly vanishes. smell is earthy.freshly baked dough. Taste is about the same as the aroma. Overall a solid beer but falls into that grey area of "what exactly is this?"

Pours clear amber / light brown with a beige head.  The aroma is malt with caramel, toffee and dough along with smooth earthy yeast.  Medium smooth body with minor carbonation.  The flavor starts out with much of the aroma traits and some toasty nuttiness.  The finish adds some phenolic traits and some basement funk.  Very nice beer.
Great cloudy amber body, but not much head. The aroma has oak barrel and fruit; very pleasant. Great weight on the palate. Dry but refreshing with hints of fruit.

from TheHopster - amber cloudy beer with moderate head and minimal lacing, notes of caramel, toffee and bread, amazing mouthfeel and great malt flavor with out being overly sweet which boosts the overall rating for me.

Bottle from Halt Time. Pours orange amber with a transient off-white head. Aroma of lightly cooked light stone fruit with an earthy touch. Med minus body. Flavor is slightly cooked light fruits, maybe even a touch of pineapple, with some mild malt, and a pervading mild earthiness. It has an amazing and wonderful flavor. Maybe ending just a touch too sweet. Judgment call.
Pours amber with a white head.  Aroma of caramel, honey, citrus.  Little bit of hops in the body - decent brew.

Bottle. Amber body with a short, fizzy, off-white head, rapidly diminishing. Aroma of grain, vegetables with a hint of spice. Leaves a strong impression of being sweet. But the flavor is only moderately sweet and lightly bitter with a light to moderate sweetness and a moderate bitterness in the finish. Medium body, creamy texture and lively carbonation. Taste of corn, pepper and a hint of earthiness. Average beer.
12oz bottle. cloudly bright gold, thin white head.  sharp citrus aroma, light spice. taste of apples, honey.

Now sold in a 12 oz bottle as well. Poured a clear amber color with a thin white head. Slow, light carbonation. Aroma has lots of pale malts with apples and light spice. Taste is sweet with lots of pale malt and fruit. Awesome blend of spices.  The finish has fruit and hops that give a nice crisp taste. Light smooth creamy body.  Overall very well balanced and some interesting flavors. Very nice. I could guzzle this beer.
Bottle. Pours clear amber gold. White head. Nose/taste of honey, toasted caramel, lightly baked bread, citrus, orange peel and florals. Light hop spiciness in finish. Medium body.

Slightly hazy copper coloured body with a very thin and fast-dying tan head. Aroma of spice, pine, malt, clean alcohol and sugars with a touch of cloves. Medium to Full-bodied; Strong alcohol and malt bite with a large metallic note and a flavour that just shows malt liquor - not much else. Thick and luscious, but not in a great way - too strong and too potent in flavours for any of the barnyardie or yeastie notes to come through. Overall, not a very good beer - way too strong and a bit too potent than Id like to see. But, this is probably expected - a good beer at the pub and in 75 cL [real] bottles, but when they mass produce a 12 ounce bottle, something gives and its not a good beer. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Liquor Outlet in Boonton, New Jersey on 08-May-2011 sampled at home in Washington on 15-June-2011.
(bottle)  Honey colored with thin white head and no lacing.  Beautiful floral & spiced hop aroma.  Smooth malt flavor with notes of spice.  Well balanced and not overpowering.  Nicely done.

A - Pours a clear copper red color with a finger of frothy head atop. The head fades down slowly to a half-finger layer leaving behind some lacing in the process.

S - Aroma is a mix of rich sweet caramel malts and just a touch of earthy malts. There is also a bit of sweet fruit esters and some yeast.

T - Starts off with some sweet toasted caramel malt and some earthy hops. There is a bit of yeast and fruity esters mixed in as well. Through the middle, some stronger yeast flavor and some spices come through. The finish is a mix of sweet malt and citrus fruits and some yeast character that lingers nicely.

M - Medium bodied with moderate lively carbonation. The beer feels really smooth and crisp with only a bit of a syrupy feeling.

D - Very drinkable. The flavors are all really nicely balanced. The toasted caramel malt flavor in particular is really nice that it avoids tasting coppery.
Bottle at Papsø. Pours clear golden with a medium off white head. The aroma is spices, caramel, citrus and fruit. The flavour is caramel, spices, yeast, fruit and bread.

Bottle from Spuyten Duyvil bottle shop in Brooklyn. Pours dark amber with light, small foamy white head. Nose and taste of apple juice and bready malts. Quite sweet. Slight tang, and but mostly sweet caramel. Weird.
Interesting. A somewhat citrusy and spiced flavor, hints of malts and yeast. Fizzy, crisp finish. Refreshing, but certainly a bit more strong than most spring and summer beers.

Bottle. Pours a lght amber color with nice head and mild carbonation. Hints of cereal, citrus and floral grass. Taste is malty with a sweet aftertaste. Interesting representation of the style, but pretty good.

12oz bottle from State Line. Seems like SH has stopped distributing in NC, hopefully just temporarily. At any rate, deep amber pour with only moderate carbonation. Very bready nose with faded fruits and just a sprig or two of things dry and grassy. Mouthfeel a bit watery, could use a bit more spice on the palate too. Taste is, expectedly, sweet malts and a not too sprightly fruit profile, not complex or dry enough for me. You could call it understated, but Id call it boring.

Clear golden amber with small head little lacing, lively... very bready/doughy aroma little hops, lots of spice.. Flavors follow suit, very spicy with big notes of bread/biscuit/dough and some grassy hops... Lively... medium body easy drinking, nice beer..
Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Clear amber - white head. Roasted, caramel, fruity, nutty, phenols, yeasty, candy, spicy notes, high malty, rubber, dried fruits.

Pint on draught.  Aromas of spice and dried fruit with malty overtones.  Pours a cloudy light orange with a white head.  Tastes are very spicy with some funk, malty as well.  Nice job on this brew overall.

Bottle at Papsø.
Clear orange coloured with a small white head.
Sweet aroma of malts, caramel, rubber and dried fruits with notes of burnt sugar.
Sweet flavour of caramel, spices and rubber with notes of dried fruits.
Spicy finish.

Pours cloudy amber with a thick foamy white head. Aroma is of sweet bread, herbs/spices, earth, dried fruits. Flavor is rather sweet with a lot of light fruits shining through. Other notes of caramel, spice, and earth. Light bodied.
12 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is toasted malty and light grassy. Bitter, grassy and slight fruity flavoured. Bitter and slight yeasty finish.

Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Dense off white head. aroma of bread, sweetness, light fruits, herbs. Flavour of herbs, light spice, some fruits and some yeast. Medium bodied. Has a sweet and light yeasted end.
Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of MaltOMeal. Pours a clear golden with a white head. Sweet malty and fruity nose. Medium body, sweet malt and fruits again with a dry finish. Pretty darn bland. 270411

Bottle.  Different label than that in the picture.  Mine says 6.5% ABV.  A pale copper pour with a skim of an off-white head.  A very unique aroma - lots of coconut, caramel, apples, lemons, oranges, apricots, and some spiciness present.  Goes down medium-bodied and crisp.  A plentiful backbone of malts with lots of caramel, toffee, and some breadiness upfront in the taste.  Kinda grainy at the end with ample fruitiness.  Apples, pears, plums, and some dried apricots in the mix.  Oak and some spiciness throughout.  Interesting and tasty stuff.
Bit of a dull beer this one. Some yeasty, and bready flavors. A hint of spice on the nose, but not much of a finish.
1st batch, 250 bottles... Murky light honey gold, nice bright white head... Champagne yeast and oak, not the best... Watery champagne super boring, yeast finish... Pass
Bright golden-amber color, with a very small head that disappears pretty quickly. Smells kind of weird, but tastes good - notes of fruit and spice, with some bitterness. A bit of sourness as well.

16 ounce pint - $6.00 at Taco Mac in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Served up a clear, orange-esque body with a thin head, white in color, a bit scant due to the generous pour you can get in these places.

Smell: Sweetish, faintly bready, with a note of caramel squares and sparsely tart juiced orchard fruits.

Taste: Sweetish at the start, then, a bit more sweet, with a sip of caramel-flavored water growing into a fuller caramel taste. A bit of bread as well as some yeast-laden dough. Fruity traces of apple and peach. No more than a hint of herb with a light bitterness imparted from the hops. Small hint of the alcohol on the drying, growingly tangy finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium carbonation.

Overall: A tasty beer and fairly refreshing, making it an ideal Springtime brew. Though, in this instance, I had it on-tap, it is nice to see it available in 12 ounce bottle.
very little head, takes a little to open up, heavy honey and flower notes on nose and palate, coriander, fruits. Nothing too subtle, flavors are a little strong for the style in my opinion

Pours light biscuit with a medium head. Aroma is fruity, with a of bread and funk. Medium in body with lively carbonation. Flavor is where its at,with lovely fruit and funky yeast. Very good and different beer.

Pale, biscuity malts, fruity, light toast, light earth, and sweet in both the aroma and flavor.  A light copper with a white head.  Medium, smooth body.  Really fun and interesting beer.  Not that the 6.2% abv is high, but it hide it very well.  Very nice.

Poured a clear orange/amber color with a thin white head.  Aroma has lots of pale malts with apples, vegetables, and corn.  Taste is creamy and sweet with lots of pale malt flavors.  Taste has some pepper and coriander.  The finish has some grape notes that remind me of a Belgian strong ale.  Hops in the finish give a nice crisp taste.  Overall very well balanced and some interesting flavors.

12 oz. Bottle at Ginger Man. Pours a clear deep golden color. Aromas of spice, apples, citrus. Taste is sweet, lemony, and herbal. Finish feels a little rustic, I guess typical for the style, not unlike a Saison. Mostly citrus and spice. Just enough hops to make it a refreshing spring beer - "Beer of March". The style is obscure to me but this was tasty.

12 oz bottle. This beer pours a light golden copper color. Great grape notes in the aroma balanced with a touch of malt aroma and slight sweetness, very reminiscent of some traditional Belgian strong ales. Great medium to light mouth feel with a somewhat silky smooth mouthfeel. Great malty sweetness up front that gives way to slight grape/wine notes and ends with a slightly dry sweetness characteristic of the malt. This is my first Biere de Garde and I can say that I am pleasantly surprised. This is an very enjoyable beer that would pair well with many different dishes however I cant compare it to the style since I havent had any others. Overall: (A).

12 oz bottle courtesy of TheEpeeist. Pours with a only slightly hazed golden body with a thin off-white head that stays for a little while. Aroma is pretty awesome while still being restrained. Glorious cereal, rich malty aroma with pear, coriander and sage. Floral. Really nice smelling! Flavors of flowers. Really floral, lightly spiced and lightly peppery. Beautiful bready and cereal like malt profile. Very easy and pleasant to drink. Nice firm bitterness in the finish that fits perfectly into place. Medium bubbles, nicely crisp. I could easily and gladly down a 6-pack of this!

Extremely well done, possibly one of my new favorites in the BdG category. Excellent!

12oz bottle from 6 pack.  glad this is sold that way!  hazy orange with very small head.  lovely bouquet aroma of flowers, candy, and sweet citrus.  flavor is malty with tart light fruits.  maybe some pineapple, apple, butter, caramel, lychee, and couple yellow sweet tarts thrown in.  medium body.  freakin fantastic!

From a 12ozer into a snifter.  Pours a beautiful blazing orange color.  Little to no head and zero lacing.  Aroma of plums, but its very faint.  Mouthfeel is stupendous.  Smooth but with some body and a small but present carbonation.  Taste is of dark fruit and spices; much like a dubbel, but without the Belgian funky taste.  Plenty of spices too.  Im not a big fan of spiced beers at all.  However, the spicing on this one is not over the top and it adds to the flavor profile.  Overall, quite a good beer and an excellent "gateway beer" from the heavy winter beers to the lighter summer beers.

12oz bottle in a tulip glass.  Pours amber with a lacy, off-white head.  Aroma of light fruits and grainy malts.  Flavor about the same with a little floral hops on the finish.  Average texture.  A decent beer.

Bottle. Pours a hazy dark gold with a nice yellow head which quickly dissipates. Aroma is apple, sweet bread, a bit floral. Flavor is a dry, crisp, refreshing with a bit of a sweet finish. Solid biere de garde.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2011 355mL thanks to tastybeer from a sixer- apparently the new format. The pour is a clear light orange with a towering, sheen, yellow head that has good retention and spotty lace. Aroma is apple cinnamon, apple pie, light maple and buttered waffle (no diacetyl). Taste is malt-forward, fruity sweet, spices, light hoppy bitterness for balance. Very clean, sessionable, nice beer to pair with food. Spot on for style and not surprising for the guy who wrote the book on Biere de Garde and Saison. 2/28/2011 7/4/7/4/14=3.6750mL 2004 ed thanks to dickinsonbeer at Shenandoah Throwdown. The pour is an orange amber. Weak, beige head. Nose is huge fresh strawberry. Taste is lighter seedy raspberry with red fruity tartness. Fresh mint comes through. Nicely tart with lemon in the finish. Totally different beer. Awesome. 8/20/2011 8/3/7/4/15=3.7

Bottle.  Beautiful malty nose, Munich sweetness with heavy spicy kick-up and a nice wave of complexity under the mild citrus and grass.  Hazy yellow body with a touch of darker golden, tiny-bubbled beige head.  Bone-dry taste with low-medium bitterness, very crisp with nice lager character, yeasty character is toned down and this is very clean, a little less spice as well but a touch of pepper on the side.  Low resin and a mild woody tones, good mix of faint bread, caramel, cereal, nuts.  Hint of orange rind.  Malt-forward medium body edges towards full, crisp and super refreshing.  Alcohol is smooth and streamlined, no warmth or burning, but does contribute body.  Fruit is hinted in the British way, and here only in the wisps of the aftertaste.  A complex monster of good craftsmanship, something I want to have a lot more of knowing now that its distributed here in 12 oz bottles.
They have this labeled as a saison with spices and for that it is a very nice beer that i enjoy alot. I think this is one of the most flavorful yet easy drinking beers i have had.

bottle.  pours a deep orange with a 2 finger white head.  aromas of spices, green apples, banana and grapes.  thin to medium body with more spice, citrus and apple notes throughout.  dry finish with lots of apple and green grape notes.

Appearance: orange with a kiss of amber under a quickly fading white head. Lingers as a thin blanket and thicker along the edges. Swirls with minimum lace.

Nose: spice and apple skins for that always tasty and aromatic cinnamon and apple pie. Pears flitter to and fro. Warm pie crust. Aromas of the fall season: cinnamon sticks, nutmeg, maple, caramelized sugar granules, and all spice. Crunchy and soft.

Palate: smooth, creamy, and soft then dry, crunchy, and spiced. Pie crust in the back golden brown and crispy. Cinnamon and nutmeg tickles while apple and pear delight, their skins crisply sweet then bitter, their essence gently permeating her body of maple and spice. Essence of autumn. Tickle of spice in breath.

Final Thoughts: Phil Markowski knows his beers and he knows how to brew them. Southampton and the beer world is better because of this, and I am more than happy to drink of his prowess.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Buy Rite - Jersey City, 11/20/10


Aroma: The nose has some lemon, yeast, a good amount of spice, and fruity notes

Appearance: It pours a clear golden-orange color with a thin, quickly dissipating, white head

Flavor: The taste is somewhat sweet, some lemon zest, spice, yeast, and herbs

Palate: It has a light-medium body, with fizzy carbonation, and a crisp finish

Overall Impression: 
My impression of this beer was pretty decent.  It is definitely a solid beer.  It is a little too fizzy for my palate, and that kind of took away from the beer in my opinion, but other then that it is pretty solid stuff.

Not a style I am familiar with but this was very tasty!  Light orange appearance,  spotty lacing,  kind of attractive.  Hefty butterscotch nose.  Syrupy feel to this, a bit of caramel, a bit of booze, somewhat moist feel, this is really nice, if only I could afford to age a bottle.

Poured a slightly hazy copper color with a white head.  Minimal bits of lacing.  The aroma was lots of sugar and a touch of citrus and tart apple.  The flavor had lots of sweet sugar going on, cut towards the finish with some fresh apple.  A sprinkling of spice thrown in.  On the thin side body-wise.  OK.

12oz bottle.  Pours a lite orange color with a small head that falls fast with no lacing. The aroma is subtle, with sweetness, citrus and a little funk. The flavor has a tart kick to start that dies off quickly leaving a well-balanced sweet citrusy tatste that is smooth on the palate. The body is on the low end of medium, nice carbonation, and the drinkability is very good.

The nose on this beer was difficult to discern.  I could detect some subtle sweetness, like butterscotch and fruitiness, but it was very subtle.  The taste was very clean and crisp with a bitterness being most prominent.  The palate was both watery and dry with lively carbonation.  If nothing else, it poured a very lovely sparkling amber with a small white head.
Sample from bottle at the Treasure Coast Beer Fest 9/11/10 Ft Pierce, FL. Very good.
12oz - Off white head over toffee colored liquid.  No real nose.  Mild palate, some malt, bitter hops.  Looking at the other ratings I wonder if I got the same beer.
12 oz. bottle.  hazy orange with a decent head. a real nice drinkable spring beer.  refrshing and crisp.
Had this at BCTC after the fest, back at the campsite.  One of the old 750s. Pours a gently hazed golden orange color.  Old caramel, light tart sourness. Fruit and tartness.  Slow caramel finish.

Poured a clear bright golden color with a tall off-white foamy head. There was a light amount of carbonation bubbles rising up in the glass. There was a mild citrus aroma. There was a nice crisp initial taste that developes a mild bitterness on the back of the throat along with some spiciness. This was a nice refreshing beer.

From a 12 oz bottle, not the fancy-schmancy bottle pictured here. Faintly cloudy orange, nice smooth white head. Toasty grainy aroma., with some spicy notes in the background. Flavor is smooth and rich, with spicy peppery notes in the finish. Some vegetable notes, as well.

12oz bottle thanks to a trade with BierBauch. Pours a dark honey color, with ample white head.  Aroma, what can be captured through the heavy foam, is pure grassy funk.   Flavor is sweet honey and lemon.... lemon and citrus, and more lemon and citrus.  A 2nd taste reveals more of the same, with a watery body and light, soda-like mouthfeel.  Carbonation is good, ABV is well disguised, but this is lightweight stuff... a little too weak on flavor for me... A nice lawn-cutter special.
Note, 12oz bottle that looks noting the the one pictured. ABV 6.5%. A lightly cloudy gold beer with tiny white head. Sweet bread scent with some spices. Taste is sweet and spicy as well as bready.

12 oz bottle. Light aroma hinted at light juicy fruits. Flavor was lightly fruiy, lightly phenolic, and had a surprisingly high hop bitterness at the finish. Nicely carbonated, with fine bubbles and a full but not heavy mouthfeel. In the end, a bit one-dimensional. Im glad the phenols and bitterness were not stronger than they were, but I wasnt a fan of either element in this beer. Copper color, small head.
Tap at the Sunset Grill in Allston outside of Boston. Aroma of gumball, cherry, and earthy hops. Bready, slightly sour flavor with great balance and interest. Tasty and very drinkable. Great stuff.

12oz bottle.  Pours a clear amber with a nice white head.  Nose is of yeast and straw, lemon and horseblanket.  Taste is of bread and spice.  Mouthfeel medium-thin, Earthy and dry to the point of dusty.  Good carbonation. Not too sweet.  Very nice
Clear dark golden color/ fleeting foam. Sweet bread, mild pit fruit aromas. medium bodied. Nice bready malt flavors with light pit fruits, easy finish.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: [12 oz. Bottle] Pours a slightly hazy orange color with a good amount of beige head. Aroma of toasted nut, caramel and some yeast. The taste is of caramel, tart fruit, yeast, grass, some spices and citrus. High carbonation and average body. Some alcohol is evident in the finish. This is a pretty good beer.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from State Line Liquors. 
It pours a clear amber color with a frothy off-white head.  The head has reasonable staying power.  The nose is musty with a bit of yeast, slight floral notes, and some dust.  The taste is malty with a bready, caramel note, a slight metallic twinge, a bit of spice, and a light fermented apple note.  Tasty and more complex than I thought it may be.  Medium bodied with above average carbonation.  The carbonation seems to form large bubbles when it hits your tongue.  The finish is slightly sweet and malty.  An interesting brew, but not as dynamic as I was hoping.

Clear, light amber/gold body with a small white head. Aroma is toffee, caramel, golden raisins and ripe pear. The taste is moderately sweet, lightly bitter with raisins, caramel, cookie dough and honey. Medium/full body is soft with moderate, but gentle carbonation. Nice.

Pours a clear golden color with a thin white head and some lacing.  Fresh aroma of golden raisins, citrus and coriander.  Crisp and refreshing with a subtle yeasty flavor along with some grapefruit and melon.  finishes wet and tart.

Light burnt orange. 12oz Bottle from Spuyten Duyvil Grocery. Nice malty aroma. Very malt forward. Alcohol shows a lot in the finish, considering the ABV. HIghly carbonated. Malty sweet, but finish is acceptably dry.

Atlanta, Ga - Hop City Craft Beer and Wine - 12 oz bottle. Medium copper pour, slight white head. Earthy aroma with some bready notes and a hint of yeast. Flavor is sweet with some hints of raisins, yeast and some baked brown bread. Mouthfeel is thick enough.
Golden amber pour with a frothy thick head. Aroma is apricot some peppery notes. Flavor is similar, fruity some spicy notes. Mouthfeel is crisp dry, but strangely alcohol hot. Good though.

On tap.Pours a semi-cloudy amber with a medium white head.Nose is fruity belgian yeasts and a touch of bread.Taste is sweet sugary malts with heavy yeasty notes and some citrus.Very drinkable session type beer but nothing Ill be rushing to pick up again...

Clear deep golden/amber pour with white head ... aroma of fruits and peppery spices a bit earthy as well ...... taste of sweet malts and fruits that give it a slight tartiness some cinnamon and peppery spice and hoppy bite that continues into the finish .... very good smooth and medium bodied that is very sessionable

On Tap at Mr. Beerys in Sarasota. Pours clear copper with thin white head. The aroma is sugar sweet with malts, sweet prunes and plums as well as a thin layer of spiciness. The taste is sweet too with malts heading toward mild roastiness. It then gets into dark fruitiness like plums, prunes and raisins. A mild spiciness tartness and earthiness surfaces about midway trying to interrupt the sweet theme going on here.
From a bottle poured a brown color with a fair amount of head.  Sweet spicy malty flavor with a quick finish.
Didnt really get much in the way of spice or fruit in this one. Seemed bland with out much distinct flavors/aromas. Will probably have to try this one again since it seems to be rated pretty high.

Bottle, pours a dark hazy dark copper color, aroma is a delicious mix of spicyness (cinnamon, clove) and sweet roastiness and caramel. Taste reflects the aroma and is a great mix between the sweet and spicy with neither too overpowering. Palate is full and a nice sweet aftertaste. Great beer, really good mix of flavors.

12 ounce bottle.  Easy drinking farmhouse offering from Southampton, a brewery Im not all that familiar with.  Aroma is middling at best, nothing really of note.  Could be Im just stuffed up and Im missing the nuances of the smell.  The beer pours a nice light gold, with a lazy, almost effervescent head.  Taste is typical of the farmhouse style, some what both sweet and sour.  Lots of floral taste and hops in this brew.  This is a beer I could drink a lot of, something I cant afford to do with the hefty 6.5% ABV that asserts itself at the end.  Overall, a very solid entry into the Farmhouse style, though there are others (Boulevards Tank No. 7) that I prefer to this one.  Still, a very decent brew and one that you can enjoy on a warm summer night.

Pours a golden yellow color with a white head. Aroma is caramel, crystal malt, raisin, some grain, slightly floral and herbal. Flavor is caramel, toast, some spice, a hint of plum, and a light bitter finish.

Pours a beautiful bright clear orange brown with a meium amount of quickly dissapating bubbly white head with lots of carbonation rising steadily from the bottom center of the glass to the top.  Aroma is of candied baked bananas with other light fruit notes and a bit of yeasty doughiness.  Flavor is very nice and light on the palate without being watery.  Slight toasted grain base with slight lemon essence and a nice grassy dry bitter hop finish.  Tad bit of alcohol warmth in the finish.  Overall, very enjoyable for a warm spring day.

Bright amber appearance with an average size head and good lacing.  Subtle aroma of toasted grains and spice.  Flavor is a little sweeter than the nose might suggest, although the spicyness is still there, especially deep in the aftertaste.  Hints of caramel and crisp fruit also show up.  Medium bodied, well carbonated mouthfeel, with a lingering, slightly sweet finish.

clear amber pour no head no retention.

tons of fruit on the nose, light malt almost no hops. Vinous quality of a light red or rose.

taste is fruitforward with light cereal and toasted malt.very smoth fish.

palate is light, clean, but maybe under carbonated a tad.

overall tasty and drinkable but not stellar.

The yeast and floral hops and some spicyness and bitterness also. Medium bodied, smooth with balanced carbonation and a slightly dry finish. Not a whole going on, but fairly easy to drink.

Not entirely impressive but a perfect springtime brew. Pours light copper eggshell head nice retension. Aromas far superior to taste with sweet yeasty malts - mostly caramel some fruity notes, light spice (ginger i think). 12oz bottle at Kumas Corner. Brewed at Latrobe, PA. Pours a clear copper/amber with decent head. Nose is musty and caramel, some slight sulfur notes. A bit of dried fruit as well. On taste, pretty straight forward tofee and caramel. Just enough bitterness to balance. Okay.
Poured a light copper color with a diminishing head. Grainy, caramel malt, slightly spicy aroma. Taste was nicely balanced between sweetness and bitterness. Not much else to say...
Thanks Barley69 for sharing. Yellow-orange pour with a white head.  Aroma of yeast, spices, fruit. Taste was the same with notes of citrus, nicely carbonated. A tasty beer.

This has been on my wants list for awhile now-and I was surprised to come across it in my local mix & match store in a 12 oz bottle. 12 oz bottle poured into a flute glass.

A- Crystal clear bright gold hue. Pours with an approximately 1 finger soapy white head that eventually fades to a thick collar. Minimal traces of lacing is left behind in the glass. Bubbles can be seen constantly rising to the top.

S-Initially the nose seems like a mumble jumble of hops, malt, and spices that are difficult to discern. Upon further investigation the hops are definitely floral, the spices are perhaps cinnamon and nutmeg, and the malt adds a nice sweetness. Nose is light and crisp.

T-Spices are the highlight upfront and there is a nice sweet malt and spicy yeast backbone. The hops kick in for the finish to add a crispness but a rush of spices and slight doughiness come through as well-then all that lingers is a minimal refreshing hop bite and a hint of spiciness. -finish is pretty abrupt and crisp. At first-it confuses the palate-but then becomes subtly complex and very drinkable.

P-Carbonation is medium and very tingly. Body is very light-consistency borders on a light biscuit-but never really completely goes there.

O- This is a very interesting, refreshing brew. I like it and think its good-but even the very minimal biscuit doughiness it offers is almost a turn-off for me. Overall I think this is a great, drinkable, light, refreshing, spicy biere de garde. I am happy it is now offered in 12 oz bottles and available in my area.

Pours a golden light amber color with a white foam head.  Has an aroma of funk and fruit.  Sweet up front nad a hoppy dry finish.  Some fruit notes mixed in.  Tasty for its style.

Pours a dark gold with a nice frothy head. Musty hop, pear, honey in the aroma. Smooth slightly sweet malt, fruity with some nice bitterness. Well done brew.

tried at belgian cafe. pour clear orange. little head. aroma is sweet. mild hops and fruits. flavor is smooth. bready and fruity with hints of apricot.
Tap at Rattlenhum - orange, yellow pour and bubbly. A bit astringent and some funk (not over the top though, in style), sweet woody-maple notes. Caramel and smooth with some faint sourness.

750ml thanks beastiefan2k - Pungent yeasty aroma with spice, caramel and cherry.  Pours brown with a small head and good lacing.  Flavor is bready and full of spice.  Subtle berry and malt finish it out.  Palate is crisp and sticky.  A tasty brew.
Draft.  Hazy oil, yellow color.  Fruity, chili, noticeably yeasty.  Very similar to a victory golden monkey in some respects.  Similar flavoring as aroma.  Flavorful, tangy, a little heavy.  Ok

On tap at Zenos Pub.This is officially one of the weirdest beers Ive ever had. Ive never had flavors like this. Unfortunately, its not necessarily a good thing. Aroma is soft. A light, minerally soap character runs through. Artificially floral, but fine. Pours a paler amber, with a really, soft velvety soap on top in off-white. Bubbly. Flavor overwhelms in this incredible dish soap flavor. Solid, blue Dawn dish soap. Gross. Im having trouble drinking this beer. It tastes like my childhood. Really  fake and overly orange flavored. But, halfway through the pint something magical happens. This character dies down and morphs into an incredibly deep and complex, earthy rich spice. My palate grows used to this overbearing soap character and starts to pick out the delicate sandalwood notes, the fresh lemongrass and some palpable cedar. Its earthy, woody and delightful. A fresh, juicy european hop cone balances this out over a mineral yeast profile, and lightly sweet tea-like sugar. The bottom third of the glass is for savoring. I dont know how to interpret this. So hard to swallow at first, so delightful in finishing. Complex...confused? Interesting, regardless. And, these days, i give points to beers that make me think twice.

Draft. Medium orange red body with thin head. Aroma is earthy, light yeast and citrus  zest. Flavor is slightly dry, earthy, lemon and citrus zest and a touch of sweetness. Pretty good but a big disappointment.
Draft: Clear amber body, small white head. Spicy citrus aroma. Citrus & yeast dominate the flavor, with a dry finish. Not bad...

Draft @ Capones.  Amber color with a light head.  Aroma is slightly sweet and bready.  Taste is bready with some light sweetness.  Surprised that I didnt like it more, but it seemed simpler than their regular BDG and saisons.  Still tasty and sessionable.

Pours a clear golden orange color with white head.  Aroma is well balance with hints of malt, hops and crisp fruit.  Flavor very similar being slightly watered down with a nice amount of maltiness, balancing out the hops and hints of apple and pear.

Rich and bready yet light and drinkable at the same time.  Crisp clean malts with a hint of nuttiness and a light sherryish oxidation.  Beautiful bright minty aroma over the sweet malts.  There is a light orange peel, soft cardamon and spice and a light fruitiness as well.  On the back there is a soft tropical pineapple character and light tartness. Philly Craft Beer Festival. Small plastic sample cup.  Clear gold with a brief white head.  Nose is grassy with honey.  Taste is honey, caramel and hops.  Medium light with moderate carb.

Hazy dark orange pour with a huge yeast cloud in suspension. A small, creamy and very tightly compacted off-white head forms and remains throughout. Light sheets of drooping lacing. Tons of sediment particles. The aroma is nicely spiced and well-rounded. Notes of coriander, Belgian yeast, noble hops, grassy plains, herb gardens, flowers in bloom, very sweet malt and peach nectar. Alcohol is undetectable. No flaws noted, no DMS, no diacetyl. Just a soft aroma of springtime. The flavor is lightly bitter, very earthy and herbal, with additions of sweet and sour fruits and rustic barnyard nuances. Hops in the aroma combine with ample but never excessive yeastiness to create a soft, succulent blend of spices. Acidity is reserved until the country-feeling finish, where bitterness and drying start to come into play. the length of the finish is superb; its also a very clean and caressing style of earthiness, leaving lingering floral hints and touches of sweet caramel. The mouthfeel is medium-bodied, with soft carbonation thats flows freely and keeps the whole experience very upbeat. Exceptionally creamy and balanced, never bogged down by any weighty, unneccessary, overdone additions. This is a fantastic blend of hops, malt and yeast. Everything is plentiful yet reserved in its agression, resulting in a feeling of authenticity and a true love and skill in brewing this difficult to master style. A wonderful beer, brewed with a degree of craftsmanship that should render any fan of the style speechless. At least, speechless long enough to soak in all these wonderful subtleties.

750 shared by Dickinsonbeer.  Hazy golden in color.  Aroma is lightly oxidized malts, fruit-apple or pear and spicy.  Taste has alot of tart fruit character, earthy yeast, and spicy.  Finishes lightly bitter and spicy.

(750ml bottle, 2005 vintage)  Pours a cloudy orange body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of apple, mustiness, orange, coriander, and caramel.  Flavor of citrus, cooked Granny Smith apples, yeast, and herbs.

Pour is clear reddish gold with a thin dense off white head...smell is fruity and earthy witgh some nice musty notes...faintly sweet at the front with nice faint sourness coming in at the end...what a treat!

Average sized creamy off-white head over a medium amber/orange body.

Dark orange with a thick semi-oily head.  Sweet  nose with malt, candy, alcohol, apricots, and honey.  Smooth firm mouthfeel adds to the slight sweetness as flavors of brown sugar, herbs, malt, and tea show up.  Finishes with herbal hops and a touch of floralness.

Much thanks to eyedrinkale for this one.  He sent it after the Red Sox beat the Yankees.

Whitish head gone in secs; heavy pearling hazy orange beer. Quite yeasty and farmyard-y smells, as well as a bit of solvent, initially; preserved vegetables, sweetish-sourish, not sharp; well-balanced. Taste: oho Mr. Markowski! Given this blind, I WOULD have said Wallonian; nail on the head. Estery, even lightly phenolic, with fruity (mainly citrus/orange) and vegetable (raw broccoli, rhubarb) notes. Alcoholimpression far above the announced 6.2%. My wife claims to taste the wheatmalt, I cant. Dry but not overly so, bit burning MF, rather alcoholic. No new aftertaste, main taste keeps slowly fading out, getting creamier with the yeast at the end of the bottle. Obviously another good one from Dr. Phil.

Pours a deep hazy orange body with a moderate head. Aroma is spices, yeast, and a bit of pepper. Flavor is the same, extremely smooth with light bitterness. Also some lighter fruits in there. Wow, best Ive had for the style so far.

Copper colored with some spotty lace and a little head. Lively carbonation. Slightly sour aroma with notes of lemons. Grassy hops with some hay and funk. Sour f lavors of citrus and spice. Peppery and bitterly malty. Tingly mouthfeel. Sour and bitter finish.
A toned down saison, and thats a good thing. Primarily a sour at palate, intense flavour not for everyone. I liked it but was not expecting this. Citrus in aroma. A wild take on the actual style

Sampled at Logans loft during GABF RateBeer party 2005.  My first Biere De Garde.  Pours hazy orange, a bit chunky, with a light and quickly dissipating head. Seems like a good choice on any hot day.

Bottle from goldtwins

Mildly citric, with a backdrop of pale malt in the flavors. Some mild spice and aged hops seem to meander about. Ah, the good do die young at times, but my patience didnt let this one hit its potential. I can see this one mellowing out quite well and becoming more balanced and a simple afternoon pleasure.

Light hazy copper, light head, nice lacing. Nose of lemon and ripe yeast, some light malts. The flavor is tart with lightly sour but sweet and hoppy enough to balance. Very creamy finish. Tasty beer. Thanks WillBlake!

text: UPDATED: JUL 22, 2005 2005 bottle from BotW, Rochester, and in my car and in my hotel rooms and in my inlaws for 7 days.   Theres such a fine line between freshness and infection sometimes and some beers, with some malt elements, deliberately flirt with and cross that line. Fantome Printemps, Victory Prima Pils, and Cisco Summer of Lager all infect a bit like this, but one can still, easily after a number of tries, get at the bottom of the base beer. One can predict the course of the decay. Others are Fantome Noel and Bells Best Brown.  I totally love these examples. This beer smells a bit like the acidity when you chew leather, but with a nice dose of going south, wet peaches. Musty and just plain brown, there is the back of the throat flat tingliness that signifies Strisselspalt - damn, its like blood and the two parts of a 9 volt on your tongue and smells like earth. Sourdough bread, a huge loaf, is the flavor. Thin, ultimately, but fantastic nevertheless. A musty experience. This guy Phil that you all talk about is indeed something.

Poured a hazy golden color with a thin, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of light barnyard, lemon citrus, grassy and lightly floral hops.  Taste of spicy citrus fruits, light vanilla, yeast, light bitterness and alcohol as well.  Cheers Steve and Mike!

Bottle acquired in trade with Eyedrinkale (thanks!). Poured a medium, cloudy amber color with an averaged sized white head. Aromas and tastes of lemons, fruits and some spices. Peppery. Lively body with a dry finish.
Tap.  Clear amber body, medium-thick white head.  Pale malt aroma with musty whole leaf hosp.  Bigger pale malt flavor with sweet honey notes and old green leaves for the "cellar-aged" hop component.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2005  Draught at d.b.a. New York. 
Cloudy dark golden. Yummy, smooth caramel malt profile. The yeast seemed very similar to Swedish Närke that gives it a creamy, big-ish, sweet, but soft body.

On tap at d.b.a. Hazy amber color, creamy off-white head fades into a thin residual cloud of a head. Aroma is an earthy chardonnay-like malt. Taste is old earthy malt... musky fruity malt, approaches an earthy malt whisky flavor, easy on the whisky though. Slightly coating mouthfeel, full body. Slight oxidized metal also.
